page.title: 2009â10 Canada women's national ice hockey team

revisions.rev:
{{NCAAIceHockeyTeamSeason |Image = |ImageSize = |Season = [[Ice hockey at the 2010 Winter Olympics|2009â10]] |Team = Hockey Canada |Sex = women |Conference = International Ice Hockey Federation |ShortConference = IIHF |ConferenceRank = |Poll#1 = |Poll#1Rank = |Poll#2 = |Poll#2Rank = |Record = 30-11 |HomeRecord = |RoadRecord = |NeutralRecord = |HeadCoach = [[Melody Davidson]] |AsstCoach1= [[Doug Lidster]] |AsstCoach2= Peter Smith |AsstCoach3= |Captain = [[Hayley Wickenheiser]] |AltCaptain = [[Jayna Hefford]], [[Caroline Ouellette]] |Arena = Father David Bauer Arena |Champion = Four Nations Cup Champions
Olympic Gold Medal
MLP Cup champions
IIHF Under 18 champions |NCAATourney = |NCAATourneyResult = }} The 2009â10 women's national hockey team will represent Canada at the 2010 Winter Olympic Games. Prior to the games, the national team will participate in various tournaments during the 2009â10 season. The team will attempt to win the gold medal at the 2010 Winter Olympics. The head coach is [[Melody Davidson]], and she is assisted by former Vancouver Canucks player [[Doug Lidster]] and Peter Smith. ==News and notes== * April 17, 2009: [[Dawson Creek, British Columbia]] was selected to host the National Womenâs team's conditioning camp from May 25 to June 17. The team was based at the EnCana Events Centre in Dawson Creek for the 24-day camp. Twenty-six players were invited for centralization and were competing for 21 roster spots for the team that would compete in [[ice hockey at the 2010 Winter Olympics]].{{cite web |url= http://www.dawsoncreek.ca/documents/17Apr09NWTDawsonCreek.pdf |title= DAWSON CREEK, B.C. TO HOST CANADAâS NATIONAL WOMENâS TEAM CONDITIONING CAMP |author= |date= April 17, 2009|work= |publisher= Hockey Canada|accessdate=8 April 2010}} * September 1, 2009: Hayley Wickenheiser became the first player on the Canadian women's hockey team to break the 300 career-point barrier Tuesday in Canada's 10-2 win over Finland at the Canada Cup.[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/59795/la_id/1.htm Game Summary] * September 21, 2009: The women's team's performance at the 2002 Winter Games was voted by fans as the No. 2 Canadian Olympic Winter Games moment of all time.[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/16980/la_id/1/ss_id/22220/nr_id/66463.htm Related News Releases] The 3-2 win over the United States gave Canada its first gold medal in women's hockey, and a measure of revenge for the loss to the Americans four years earlier in Nagano, Japan. The accomplishment will be featured on a Canadian circulation coin to be released on November 17, 2009. The artist of the coin is Jason Bouwman.[http://www.mint.ca/store/news/royal-canadian-mint-releases-25cent-coin-celebrating-men%19s-hockey-7000006?cat=News+releases&nId=700002&parentnId=600004&nodeGroup=About+the+Mint Welcome - Royal Canadian Mint] * On February 5, Hayley Wickenheiser made news when she put a teenage Dane Phaneuf in a headlock. Phaneuf plays for the Edmonton South Side Athletics, 15 to 17year old boys from the Alberta Midget Hockey League. Phaneufâs older brother, Dion plays in the National Hockey League. The reason for the headlock was that there were concerns about Phaneufâs aggressive play. The video highlight of the headlock made national news.{{cite web |url= http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/wireStory?id=9767262 |title= Canada Women's Hockey Preps for Vancouver Vs. Boys |author= |date= February 6, 2010|work= |publisher= ABC News|accessdate=7 April 2010}} * [[Melody Davidson]] revealed after the gold medal game that the team left the Olympic Village for two exhibition games against the Vancouver Northwest Giants boys AAA midget team during the Olympics. The first game was held the night before the opening ceremonies. The final game was on February 19.{{cite web |url= http://www.owha.on.ca/esso_2003_winners.asp |title= http://www.thehockeynews.com/articles/31760-THN-at-the-Olympics-Canada-sits-atop-hockey-world-but-by-too-big-a-margin.html|author= Ken Campbell|date= February 25, 2010|work= |publisher= The Hockey News |accessdate=8 April 2010}} * February 26: The International Olympic Committee announced that it would investigate the after ice celebration of several Canadian women's hockey players. The cause for the investigation is the concern about the use of beer and cigars on the ice in Vancouver. Another cause for concern was 18-year-old Marie-Philip Poulin was drinking alcohol on the ice{{cite web |url= http://www.torontosun.com/sports/vancouver2010/photos/2010/02/26/13037781.html |title= Women's hockey Olympic celebrations |author= |date= February 26, 2010|work= |publisher= Toronto Sun|accessdate=7 April 2010}} (the legal drinking age in British Columbia is 19.) The team had been on the ice for more than 70 minutes after the medal ceremony (only media and arena staff were present).{{cite web |url= http://sports.yahoo.com/olympics/vancouver/blog/fourth_place_medal/post/IOC-to-investigate-Canadian-women-s-hockey-team-?urn=oly,224338 |title= IOC to investigate Canadian women's hockey team for celebration |author= Chris Chase |date= February 26, 2010|work= |publisher= Yahoo Sports|accessdate=7 April 2010}} The antics drew heavy criticism from within, and outside of, Canada, but also considerable support from Canadian fans.. * February 28: After winning the gold medal, Canada has once again earned the number one ranking in the IIHF Womenâs World Ranking. Canada's men are also ranked first in the IIHF Menâs World Ranking.[http://www.iihf.com/channels10/olympics-2010/news/news-singleview-world-championship-2009/article/canada-takes-over.html?tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=3471&cHash=e12d902ce9 Canada takes over] * April 12:Meghan Agosta, Jayna Hefford and Cherie Piper were among thirteen Canadian Olympic medallists attending the home opener of the [[2010 Toronto Blue Jays season]] on Monday, April 12 versus the Chicago White Sox. The medallists will enjoy a meet and greet with the Blue Jays players at a pre-game batting practice and participate in the Ceremonial First Pitch. {{cite web |url= http://www.olympic.ca/en/news/canadian-olympic-medallists-celebrated-blue-jays-game/ |title= Canadian Olympic Medallists Celebrated at Blue Jays Game |author= |date= April 12, 2010|work= |publisher= Canadian Olympic Committee|accessdate=12 April 2010}} * June 28:The Canadian men's and women's hockey teams picked up rings commemorating their double gold victory in Vancouver. The rings are diamond-encrusted with the Olympic logo in the centre. The rings were handed out as part of Hockey Canada's "Canada Celebrates" ceremony in the Alberta capital.{{cite web |url=http://www.tsn.ca/canadian_hockey/story/?id=326001l|title= Canada's gold medal hockey teams hailed as heroes at ceremony|author= The canadian press|date=June 28, 2010 |work= |publisher= tsn.ca|date=30 June 2010}} ==Hockey cards== * Various members of the national team are featured in the 2009-10 O-Pee-Chee Hockey Card set, distributed by [[Upper Deck]].[http://sports.upperdeck.com/Hockey/cardset.aspx?q=5&r=1&sid=53773 Upper Deck Sports | Hockey - Athlete] The checklist is as follows: {| class="wikitable" style="width:80%;" |- style="text-align:center; background:black; color:red;" | '''Card number''' || '''Player''' |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" | CB-BK || Becky Kellar |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-CL||Charline LabontÃ© |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-CM||Carla MacLeod |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-CO||Caroline Ouellette |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-CS||Colleen Sostorics |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-CW||Catherine Ward |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-GA||Gillian Apps |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-GF||Gillian Ferrari |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-GK||Gina Kingsbury |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-HI||Haley Irwin |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-HW||Hayley Wickenheiser |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-JB||Jennifer Botterill |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-JH||Jayna Hefford |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-KS||Kim St-Pierre |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-MA||Meghan Agosta |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-MM||Meaghan Mikkelson |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-MP||Marie-Philip Poulin |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-RJ||Rebecca Johnston |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-SS||Shannon Szabados |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |CB-SV||Sarah Vaillancourt |} ==International exhibition games== * January 1: [[Jayna Hefford]] scored the only goal in the shootout goal (Charline LabontÃ© stopped all three American shooters) as Canada beat the U.S. by a score of 3-2. Before the match, Hefford was honoured for reaching the 200-game plateau in November.[http://www2.canada.com/theprovince/news/sports/story.html?id=ff26c70d-76ff-446b-901c-ec688eee5ad4 Women's hockey real winner this night] The game was played in front of 16,347 fans at Scotiabank Place. It was the largest Canadian crowd to watch a women's hockey game, surpassing the previous mark of 15,163 set Jan. 26, 1998 at the Calgary Saddledome.http://ca.news.yahoo.com/s/capress/100101/sports/hko_women_us_canada {{dead link|date=March 2011}} {| class="wikitable" style="width:80%;" |- style="text-align:center; background:black; color:red;" | '''Date''' || '''Opponent''' || '''Location''' || '''Time'''|| '''Score''' |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="bbffbb" | Aug. 15, 2009 || Sweden || Calgary, AB || 19:00 pm|| 7-2[http://www.canadianhockey.ca/index.php/ci_id/65308/la_id/1.htm Game Summary] |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="bbffbb" | Oct. 5, 2009 || [[2009â10 USA Hockey national women's team|USA]] || Victoria, BC (Save on Foods Centre) || 19:00 PM || 3-1[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/66318/la_id/1.htm Game Summary] |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="bbffbb" | Oct. 16, 2009 || USA || Spokane, WA (Spokane Arena) || 19:00 PM|| 5-2[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/66827/la_id/1.htm Game Summary] |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="bbffbb" | Dec. 12, 2009 || USA || Denver, CO (Magness Arena)[http://www.usahockey.com/Qwest%20Tour%202009/default.aspx?NAV=AF_01&ID=241072 USA Hockey] || TBD|| 4-2[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/66828/la_id/1.htm Game Summary] |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="bbffbb" | Dec. 15, 2009 || USA || Calgary, AB || TBD||6-2[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/66829/la_id/1.htm Game Summary] |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="bbffbb" | Dec. 30, 2009 || USA || St. Paul, MN ([[Xcel Energy Center]]) || 19:00 PM|| 2-1[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/66830/la_id/1.htm Game Summary] |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="bbffbb" | Jan. 1, 2010 || USA || Ottawa, ON || 19:00 PM|| 3-2 (Shootout) |}[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/61666/la_id/1.htm Schedule/Results] ==Intrasquad games== ===Under-22 series=== The Canadian national team participated in a three-game series against the Canadian under-22 national team. All games were played at the Father David Bauer Olympic Arena in Calgary, Alberta. {| class="wikitable" style="width:80%;" |- style="text-align:center; background:black; color:red;" | '''Date''' || '''Score''' || '''Notes''' |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" | Aug. 17, 2009 || National team, 4-3 || Two points by Meghan Agosta[http://hurstathletics.com/news/2009/8/18/WHOCK_0818094759.aspx Mercyhurst College Athletics - Agosta Leads Canadian National Team Over Under-22 Squad] |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" | Aug. 18, 2009 || National team, 5-2 || Two points by Meghan Agosta[http://hurstathletics.com/news/2009/8/19/WHOCK_0819095826.aspx Mercyhurst College Athletics - Agosta Helps Out as National Team Downs Under-22, 5-2] |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" | Aug. 20, 2009 || National team, 10-0 || Two goals by Meghan Agosta[http://hurstathletics.com/news/2009/8/21/WHOCK_0821094749.aspx Mercyhurst College Athletics - Agosta, National Team Sweeps Under-22 Team] and Hayley Wickenheiser |} ===Red and White Games=== * The national team competes in intersquad games in Calgary. One team dons red jerseys, while the other team wears white jerseys. {| class="wikitable" style="width:80%;" |- style="text-align:center; background:black; color:red;" | '''Date''' || '''Time'''|| '''Location''' || '''Notes''' |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" | Sept. 28, 2009 || 19:00 PM || White 5, Red 2[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/66571/la_id/1.htm Game Summary] || Hayley Wickenheiser scored four goals and Haley Irwin added one of her own for White in its victory over Red |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" | Oct. 26, 2009[http://www.canadianhockey.ca/index.php/ci_id/64988/la_id/1.htm Schedule/Results - Midget Series] || || |} ==Tournaments== Jayna Hefford has scored 19 goals in 20 games versus boys' midget AAA teams during this pre-Olympic season.[http://www.ctvolympics.ca/hockey/news/newsid=23388.html CTV Olympics Store] ===Icebreaker Tournament=== * All games were held at Father David Bauer Arena in Calgary. {| class="wikitable" style="width:80%;" |- style="text-align:center; background:black; color:red;" | '''Date''' || '''Opponent''' || '''Score''' |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="bbffbb" | Sept. 24, 2009 || Calgary Flames Midget AAA || Win, 3-2[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/65309/la_id/1.htm Game Summary] |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="bbffbb" | Sept. 25, 2009 || Calgary Bisons || Win, 6-5 |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="bbffbb" | Sept. 26, 2009 || Calgary Royals || Win, 3-2[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/66307/la_id/1.htm Game Summary] |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="bbffbb" | Sept. 27, 2009 || Calgary Royals (Championship Game)|| Win, 5-4[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/66543/la_id/1.htm Game Summary] |} ===2009 Canada Cup=== * All games were held at [[General Motors Place]] in Vancouver, British Columbia. {| class="wikitable" style="width:80%;" |- style="text-align:center; Collins||0||2||2|| |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" | Tessa Bonhomme||0 ||1 ||1 || |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" |Carla McLeod ||0 ||1 ||1 || |} ===Goaltenders=== Szabados has faced 116 shots in five games. St-Pierre has faced 85 shots in four games. * September 3, 2009, was goalie Shannon Szabados' first loss (2-4 versus US). Up to that point, her record was 9-0.[http://insideprofessionalsports.blogspot.com/2009/12/jayna-hefford-leads-team-canada-to-6-2.html Inside the Locker Room: Jayna Hefford leads Team Canada to 6-2 win over US] {| class="wikitable" style="width:80%;" |- style="text-align:center; background:black; color:red;" | '''Player''' || '''Games played''' || '''Minutes''' || '''Goals against''' || '''Wins''' || '''Losses'''|| '''Ties'''|| '''Shutouts'''|| '''Save %'''|| '''Goals against average''' |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" | Shannon Szabados || 5 || 300 || 10 || 4 || 0|| 0 ||0|| ||2.00 |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" | Kim St. Pierre || 4 || 240 || 12 || 4 || 0 || 0 || 1 || || 3.00 |} ==2010 Olympics== In the first three games, Canada took their goal total at the 2010 Games to 41 in three matches. * February 14: Canada defeated Slovakia by a record-setting score of 18-0 in their opening game of the 2010 Vancouver Olympic Winter Games on Saturday. Jayna Hefford and Meghan Agosta scored three goals each for Canada who set a record for the most lopsided win women's Olympic hockey tournament history. Canada also held the previous record for the biggest blowout, a 16-0 demolition of host Italy at the Torino 2006 Olympic Games. Hefford finished with a game-high six points in front of a crowd of 16,496 at the Canada Hockey Place arena. Slovakia was making their first appearance in the women's tournament as they were promoted to the top level after winning the qualifying event. Slovakia was outshot 67-9.[http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/afp-news/ice-hockey--canada-crushes-slovakia-18-0-in-record-win_277240xC.html Vancouver 2010 Winter Olympics | Olympic Games Photos, Videos, & News] ** International ice hockey chief [[RenÃ© Fasel]] defended the inclusion of women's hockey in the Olympic Games Sunday by stating one-sided blowouts like Canada's 18-0 thrashing of Slovakia were once a part of the men's game.[http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/afp-news/ice-hockey--women's-battling-growing-pains_278288xM.html Vancouver 2010 Winter Olympics | Olympic Games Photos, Videos, & News] The IIHF president also said hockey fans are going to have to get used to the disparity between superpowers Canada and the US and the rest of the Olympic field until they can develop more female players in non-traditional hockey-playing countries. The Canadian women said they never thought twice Saturday about not running up the score against lowly Slovakia doesn't help their cause. In fact, some players stated they were giving Slovakia a taste of its own medicine as the Slovaks qualification to the Olympics included an 82-0 thumping of hockey newcomer Bulgaria.[http://sports.espn.go.com/oly/news/story?id=3577150 Bulgaria gives up 139 shots on goal in 82-0 women's hockey loss - Olympics - ESPN] * On February 17, Hayley Wickenheiser became the all-time leading Olympic goal scorer as Canada defeated Sweden 13-1. Wickenheiser reached her record total of 16 career Olympic goals by scoring once on Wednesday as Canada followed up their 18-0 win over Slovakia and 10-1 defeat of Switzerland.[http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/afp-news/ice-hockey--wickenheiser--canada-shatter-scoring-records_282774sz.html Vancouver 2010 Winter Olympics | Olympic Games Photos, Videos, & News] In addition, Meghan Agosta scored a record third Olympic hat-trick in the match against Sweden to move on to eight goals in this tournament, equalling Danielle Goyette's record for most goals in one Olympic tournament, set in 1998. ===Schedule=== {| class="wikitable" style="width:80%;" |- style="text-align:center; background:black; color:red;" | '''Date''' || '''Opponent''' || 3|| 180 || 1 || 3 || 0 || 1 || 98.0|| 0.33 |} ==Under-22 team== * The head coach of the under-22 team was [[Margot Page]].[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/63481/ss_id/63263/la_id/1.htm NR.095] She was assisted by Jim Fetter of Wayne State University and Stephanie White of Ryerson University. * January 10: [[Vicki Bendus]] scored a goal and added two assists for the Canadian national women's under-22 team in the gold medal game of the 2010 MLP Cup. Canada defeated Switzerland, 9-0 in Ravensburg, Germany. The Canadian team won all four of their games by a combined score of 24-4, and secured their seventh goal medal in the past eight years. In three games, Bendus, [[Jesse Scanzano]] and Bailey Bram (from the [[Mercyhurst Lakers women's ice hockey]] team) combined for seven goals and 18 points.[http://www.hurstathletics.com/news/2010/1/10/WHOCK_0110104229.aspx Mercyhurst College Athletics - Lakers Help Canada to Gold at MLP Cup] Benuds and Bram were tied for the tournament lead in scoring, and Bendus was named the tournament's top forward.[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/70202/la_id/1.htm Game Summary] ===MLP Cup=== {| class="wikitable" style="width:80%;" |- style="text-align:center; background:black; color:red;" | '''Date''' || '''Opponent''' || '''Score''' || '''Record''' || '''Notes''' |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" | Monday January 4 ||Germany ||5-1[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/70078/la_id/1.htm Game Summary]|| 1-0 || Emmanuelle Blais and Carolyne Prevost had two assists |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" | Tuesday January 5 ||Switzerland||4-1[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/69042/la_id/1.htm Game Summary]|| 2-0 || Natalie Spooner and Mallory Deluce finished with a goal and an assist each |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" | Thursday January 7 ||Germany||7-0[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/69044/la_id/1.htm Game Summary]|| 3-0 || Brianne Jenner and Bailey Bram finished with a goal and two assists each |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" | Friday January 8 ||Sweden||4-3 (OT)[http://www.hockeycanada.ca/index.php/ci_id/69045/la_id/1.htm Game Summary]|| 4-0 || Natalie Spooner scored the game winning goal |- style="text-align:center;" bgcolor="" | Saturday January 9 ||Switzerland||9-0|| 5-0 || Canada won gold at the MLP Cup for the seventh time in eight years |} ==Under-18 team== * March 1: Hockey Canada announced its roster for the team competing at the third ever IIHF Under 18 Women's World Championships. The head coach is Dan Church and he is assisted by Pierre Alain and Lisa Jordan.
